subject: RE: [junit] how to avoid multiple initialization ?
msgSnippet: There s also the junit.extensions.TestSetup class that comes with junit. It s a decorator designed for this purpose, doing one time initialization. Good luck,
messageBody:
There's also the junit.extensions.TestSetup class that comes with junit.
It's a decorator designed for this purpose, doing one time initialization.

Good luck,
-Larry

-----Original Message-----
From: Kris Henderson [mailto:khenderson@...]
Sent: Monday, July 21, 2003 12:54 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] how to avoid multiple initialization ?



Try something like this:

public class TestMyClass extends TestCase
{
private static boolean doSetup = true;

public TestMyClass(java.lang.String testName)
{
super(testName);
}

public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
{
junit.textui.TestRunner.run(suite());
}

public static Test suite()
{
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite(TestMyClass.class);
return suite;
}

public void setUp()
{
if (doSetup)
{
doSetup();
doSetup = false;
}
}

public void doSetup()
{
}

public void testSomething()
{
}

public void testSomethingElse()
{
}
}

Kris

> Dear all,

> could you help in the following:
>
> Several test are united in one test class. I want some
> initialization to be done ONCE for all tests. I sow only 2
> possibilities where to place initialization code:
> 1) setUp() method
> 2) constructor
> But both are called n times, where n is number of testXXX()
> methods. For n=2 it looks like:
> constructor is called
> constructor is called
> .setUp is called
> testOne is called
> .setUp is called
> testTwo is called
>
> So, could you please advice how to achive one-time initialization.
>
> // SAMPLE CODE THAT PRODUCES ABOVE OUTPUT
> package itc_m.pass.test;
>
> import junit.framework.*;
>
> public class TestOfOneTimeInit extends TestCase {
>
> public static Test suite() {
> return new TestSuite(TestOfOneTimeInit.class);
> }
>
> public TestOfOneTimeInit(){
> System.out.println("constructor is called");
> }
>
> protected void setUp(){
> System.out.println("setUp is called");
> }
>
> public void testOne(){
> System.out.println("testOne is called");
> }
>
> public void testTwo(){
> System.out.println("testTwo is called");
> }
>
> }
